message: Is it just me?
Me too :(
I usually just highlight what I'm about to delete and paste over it... something like vi"p

Here's a scenario that frequently frustrates me: I yank something, but forget to specify a register. Then I move to the place where I want to paste it, but there's something in the way that I have to delete first. I delete it, and in doing so, clobber the contents of my default register. Then I hit `p` to paste, forgetting that I've just overwritten the thing I previously yanked. And what do I get? The thing I just deleted is placed right back where it was.
not just you... I do it too...
Type in :reg
...which is exactly the same as the 'cut' operation - as in cut, copy and paste.
I do that all the time...
I know of a handful of ways to prevent this from happening, and yet I still find myself making this mistake again and again.
@codekoala yeah, that works too, but then you end up overwriting the default register with the text that you remove.
@alfredodeza right! That's the least bad solution, IMHO, but it still requires a little forethought.
that is a zero not an uppercase o :)
Vim's 'delete' operation removes the specified text from the document, and copies it into a register.
There is a default register you can use ("0) that always holds the last yanked line/character. So even if you delete/cut or anything you can do "0p
you'll see a listing of your recent yanks
if you need, say the third yank, "3p
true, that does bother me sometimes :)
...hence the existence of the yankring plugin: http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=1234
When Vim talks about making a 'deletion', what it's actually doing is a 'cut'.
@asenchi that's another thing that annoys me - the registers 1-9 store the 9 most recent chunks of deleted text, but yanked text is not included in those registers
I think the confusion partly arrises from the terminology.
:reg has horrible output
If you want to truly delete something in Vim, you have to 'save' it to the 'blackhole register'

There are so many things about Vim that seem crazy at first, but once you've grokked them they make perfect sense. I think I understand how Vim's registers work, but it still doesn't make sense to me.
I'm not keen to admit that there's something about Vim that I dislike, so I hope that I'm missing something here.
+1 for YankRing.  Install, bind a key to :YRShow, never lose your pastes ever again.  It's also nice because you can paste as normal and then use ^P to cycle back through previous items.
does it work like emacs' kill-ring?
@alfredodeza I was unaware of that register 0 dealie -- thanks! Will be useful.
like how i can do ct" (change til a quotation mark), i want to do "paste over text until the quotation mark"
yeah, i typicall use "0p in these situations. i wish there was a way to paste over existing text without entering visual mode first
"_d<movement>
(sorry, those were @telemachus)
(which I've never heard of, frankly)

@akahn  @nelstrom If you want to replace after yanking use <movement>"_dP Or even better, use this plugin https://github.com/vim-scripts/ReplaceWithRegister.git to get nice bindings (<movement>gr, <movement>grr) and get around caveats. If you'll add gR on top of that you'll get pretty consistent syntax gr - d, grr - dd, gR - D
That's my primary reason to use MacVim. For small stuf I use yanking, no steps in between yanking and putting, but for the bigger stuff I use Cmd+C and Cmd+V.
@akahn Using this plugin you would do grt" I use a lot yi( or di( with gri( to replace arguments of a function. Oh and <movement> goes obviously after d and gr in examples above.
I'm glad I could help you back after getting so much from vimcasts:)
"_y<movement> also "works", but is somewhat useless
@mehowte this looks like a nice solution - thanks for the tip.
(/dev/null for yanks...?)
Is there a way to delete straight to nowhere?
I'm seeing nelstrom's comment about saving to the blackhole register
Apologies but I'm coming in late and still catching up on scroll...
and if I understand the primary point of such a deletion is to delete but not overwrite the default register, right? (That is, that's when you would really want this.)
@jagill thanks

@telemachus Yes you yank something then "_d<movement> to delete into black hole and P to paste it. It is the replace pattern for people who doesn't like to go into visual mode without good reason;) And that plugin I've mentioned encapsulates this pattern binds it with gr (think go replace:) and protects you from few unwanted edge cases.
@nelstrom - Thanks - already liking the the look of ReplaceWithRegister. Just installed it.
@telemachus for more on the blackhole register, look up :help quote_ (http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/change.html#quote_)
@mehowte Excellent - I'll checkout ReplaceWithRegister
